results.title: Il Trittico
results.creator_credit: Sylvano Bussotti, National Video Corporation, Radiotelevisione Italiana and Brian Large
results.brief_description: Giacomo Puccini’s “Il Trittico” was recorded live in 1983 at the Teatro alla Scalla, Milan, and featured the Chorus and Orchestra of La Scala, Milan with chorus master Romano Gandolfi and conductor Gianandrea Gavazzeni. “Il Trittico” consists of three one act operas each contrasting in its mood and style and yet all three combining to make an interesting and entertaining program. “Il Tabarro” - music by Puccini, libretto by Giuseppe Adami. A tragic domestic drama of clandestine love, desire and death set in Paris and featuring singers Piero Cappuccilli (Michele, a bargeman), Sylvia Sass (Michele’s wife, Giorgetta) and Nicola Martinucci (Luigi, a penniless stevedore and Giorgetta’s lover). “Suor Angelica” - music by Puccini, libretto by Giovacchino Forzano. A sad and gentle tale of a noble, but disgraced, princess who sought solace in becoming a nun. Set in a convent in the latter part of the 17th century and featuring singers Rosalind Plowright (Sister Angelica, the disgraced princess), Dunja Vejzovich (the Princess and aunt to Sister Angelica) and Maria Grazia Allegri (the Abbess). “Gianni Schicchi” - music by Puccini, libretto by Giovacchino Forzano. A witty and humorous tale of family, greed and deception set in 13th century Florence and featuring singers Juan Pons (Gianni Schicchi), Cecilia Gasdia (Lauretta, Schicci’s daughter), Yuri Marusin (Rinuccio, Lauretta’s lover) and Eleonora Jankovic (Zita, Rinuccio’s aunt). Sung in Italian with no English subtitles. Contains guidebook with English translations.

results.title: Il re pastore
results.creator_credit: John Cox, Cami Video ORF ZDF Production and Brian Large
results.brief_description: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart’s “Il re Pastore” is presented by the International Mozarteum Foundation Salzburg in association with the Landestheater Salzburg for the 1989 Mozart Week. It tells the story of Alessandro (Alexander the Great) who has freed the city of Sidon from the tyranny of Strato and decides to restore the throne to the legitimate heir. Alessandro discovers that the heir is Aminta, a shepherd. Sung in Italian. Contains Libretto by Pietro Metastasio. Performers include: Angela Maria Blasi, Sylvia McNair, Iris Vermillion, Jerry Hadley, Claes H. Ahnsjo. Academy of St Martin in the Fields (London) conducted by Sir Neville Marriner. Staged by John Cox.

results.title: Il Duce
results.creator_credit: Julia Spark and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “History in action”.
Although Italy has a king, Prime Minister Benito Mussolini is the one called “Il Duce”, the leader. Between 1919 and 1925, Mussolini promised his people political stability, law and order, prosperity, social reform and an empire. In June 1934, Mussolini met Hitler for the first time in Venice. It was rumoured that Mussolini felt himself superior to Hitler and that the relationship between the two dictators was strained. This program looks at whether Italy was strong enough to be a Great Power and whether Hitler would be an ally or competitor.

results.title: Ikwe
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Michael Scott, Ches Yetman and Norma Bailey
results.brief_description: A young Ojibwa girl of 1770, Ikwe awakens one night from a disturbing dream about a strange man. The arrival of a young Scottish fur trader transforms her dream into reality. Marrying him, Ikwe leaves her village on the shores of Georgian Bay. Although the union promises prosperity for her tribe, it means hardship and isolation for Ikwe. Values and customs clash until, finally, the events of Ikwe’s dream unfold with tragic clarity. Part one of the series entitled Daughters of the Country.

results.title: If***
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Memorial, Michael Medwin and Lindsay Anderson
results.brief_description: This film captures the particular ethos of a public school and the general flavour of any highly structured community, combining an allegorical thrust with a clear-eyed exploration of an essentially British institution. Constructed in 8 chapters introduced by titles in a Brechtian schema, a surrealistic edge (Anderson prefers ‘heightened reality’) is brought to events in the later sections as the line is blurred between fantasy and reality, an approach reflecting the influence of Zero de Conduite. Although conceived several years earlier, the timing of “If’s” release coinciding with the events of May 1968 ensured its success against the expectations of Paramount’s executives.
